lesson.name: Unit 4: Part 3: Problem-Solving in English Language Acquisition

page.title: Overview
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-37.mp3

Audio transcript


Problem solving in educational settings is called problem-based learning. Problem-based approaches have long been used in English language acquisition programs.

21st-century problems often involve technology, which is why the PIAAC included a PSTRE component in the 2012 survey of adult skills. A modern adaptation of problem-based learning in second language acquisition includes problems that are embedded in technology, as well as use of technology as a solution.

Problem-solving in educational settings is called problem-based learning. Problem-based approaches have long been used in English-language-acquisition programs.

21st-century problems often involve technology, which is why the PIAAC included a PSTRE component in the 2012 survey of adult skills.

A modern adaptation of problem-based learning in second language acquisition includes problems that are embedded in technology, as well as use of technology as a solution.

 

To Go Deeper


Read Problem-Based Learning and Adult English Language Learners, by Mathews-Aydinli, available at http://www.cal.org/caela/esl_resources/briefs/problembased.html and Second Language Acquisition in Adults: From Research to Practice, by Moss & Feldman-Ross, available at http://www.cal.org/caela/esl_resources/digests/SLA.html.

page.title: Integrating PSTRE Into English Language Acquisition
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-38.mp3

Audio transcript


In a problem-based approach, the problem provides a context and a purpose for learning new skills, including language and technology skills. It is appropriate for adult English language acquisition because it promotes interaction among students, is relevant to students’ lives and goals, and leverages and builds background knowledge as students learn (or define) the problem and the language needed to talk about the problem. Problem-based learning builds collaborative skills as students work together to define the problem, collect information, and evaluate possible solutions. For the same reasons, problem-based learning promotes active, engaged learning.

Problem-based learning can provide the curriculum for an entire course or program, but problem-based activities can also be used to supplement other types of approaches, including project-based learning, contextualized instruction, topic or theme-based learning, and Learners’ Lives as Curriculum®.

Problem-based learning is appropriate for adult English language acquisition because it

  • Promotes interaction among students

  • Is relevant to students’ lives and goals

  • Leverages and builds background knowledge

  • Builds collaborative skills

  • Promotes active, engaged learning

Problem-based learning can provide the curriculum for an entire course or program, or supplement other types of approaches, including

  • Project-based learning

  • Contextualized instruction

  • Topic or theme-based learning

  • Learners’ Lives as Curriculum®

page.title: Problem Based Activities
page.contents:
Consumerism Buying a Computer Problem
Education Parent-Teacher Conference Problem
Employment Online Job Search Problem
Community Find a Volunteer Opportunity that Fits Your Schedule and Interest Problem
Daily Living Where to Find Fresh and Local Foods that aren't too Expensive Problem

Problem-based activities can be added to almost any curriculum unit. These examples add a problem-based activity to each topical unit.

page.title: Design a PSTRE Activity
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-40.mp3

Audio transcript


In order to design a PSTRE problem to integrate into your teaching, first select a class into which you would like to integrate a problem-based activity. To make your selection, review your units for that class and elect a unit that would benefit from the supplementation that a problem-based activity would provide—for example, if you need to build language review into a unit, or build in additional practice with digital skills introduced in the unit, or if further speaking practice through interaction is needed. Then design a problem-based activity that would benefit the unit. Build from the background knowledge, language, and content of the unit that you have selected. Be sure to avoid overspecifying the problem. Defining the problem is part of the problem-solving process. The examples in this unit model the appropriate level of detail. Of course, it goes without saying that you will match the level of difficulty of the problem to the language level and digital skills of your students.

Keep mind the types of things that make problems more difficult to solve. Problems are more difficult when the context is unfamiliar, the application or software is unfamiliar, the solution requires multiple applications, the solution requires multiple steps, or the required information is embedded in a lot of unfamiliar language. Problems are also more difficult to solve when there is a barrier or are multiple barriers, such as a defunct website, a broken link, or conflicting information.

Select a class into which you would like to integrate a problem-based activity.

Review your units for that class. Select a unit that would benefit from the supplementation that a problem-based activity would provide (e.g., language review, practice with digital skills, or further opportunity for interaction).

Design a problem-based activity that would benefit the unit. Build from the background knowledge, language, and content of the curricular unit that you have selected.

Don’t overspecify the problem. Defining the problem is part of the problem-solving process. Use the examples in this unit for the appropriate level of detail.

Match the level of difficulty of the problem to the language level and digital skills of your students.

Share the activity you create with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

Problems are more difficult to solve when the

  • Context is unfamiliar

  • Application or software is unfamiliar

  • Solution requires multiple applications

  • Solution requires multiple steps

  • Required information is embedded in a lot of unfamiliar language

  • There is a barrier (e.g., defunct website, broken link, conflicting information)

page.title: The PSTRE Activity: Understand the Nature of the Problem
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-41.mp3

Audio transcript


The first few times that you include a PSTRE activity, you may want to have the whole class work on the same problem. After several successful experiences, assign groups to work on different problems.

Start the activity by introducing the problem. This introduction includes
-Connecting the problem to the unit
-Explaining the importance of PSTRE and giving real examples
- Discussing the context of the problem and students’ (as well as your) personal experience with similar problems
- Reviewing relevant vocabulary from the unit

Then work together to understand the nature of the problem by creating a pair or small-group activity in which the students work together to identify the goals of the problem and predict what the solution may look like. When they have finished, come back together to compare different answers and discuss them.

The first few times that you include a PSTRE activity, you may want to have the whole class work on the same problem. After several successful experiences, assign groups to work on different problems.  

Introduce the problem.

  • Connect the problem to the unit for the students.

  • Explain the importance of PSTRE.

  • Discuss the context of the problem and students’ (and teacher’s) personal experience with similar problems.

  • Review relevant vocabulary from the unit.

Understand the nature of the problem.

Create a pair or small-group activity in which the students work together to

  • Identify the goals of the problem

  • Predict what the solution may look like

Come back together to compare different answers and discuss them.

page.title: The PSTRE Activity: Make a Plan
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-42.mp3

Audio transcript


The next step is to identify the resources available. Resources may include websites, people, and experience. For lower level students, you may want to provide some resources that you’ve preselected. For example, in the Online Job Search Problem, the jobscout website is appropriate for adult English language learners and will be a good resource to add. In the buying a computer problem, the everyoneon website will be helpful for adult English language learners. For higher level students, working together to find resources with some general guidance from you is a better option. Then work together to decide on the amount of time that can be spent on finding a solution. This is an important part of the problem-solving process, and it is important to model it regularly. People proficient in problem solving often perform this step without thinking, but it needs to be made explicit for adult English language learners.

Next, design the format of the solution. You may want to provide guidance for your students by creating a simple work sheet that gives the questions to answer. For lower level students, you might want to give more support and provide sentence frames to use. Of course, the amount of modeling and guidance that you provide depends on the language level and digital literacy skill of your students.

Used with permission from JobScout.

www.myjobscout.org

Used with permission.

EveryoneOn.org/adulted

Identify the resources available.

Resources may include websites, people, and experience.  

  • For lower level students, you may want to provide some resources that you’ve preselected. For example, in the Online Job Search Problem, the jobscout website is appropriate for adult English language learners and will be a good resource to add. In the Buying-a-Computer Problem, the everyoneon website will be helpful for adult English language learners.  

Predetermine the amount of time that students should spend on finding a solution.

Design the format of the solution.

You may also provide guidance by creating a simple worksheet to give the questions to answer and possibly sentence frames to use in response.

The amount of modeling and guidance that you provide depends on the language level and digital literacy skill of your students.   

To Go Deeper


To learn more about how your students can get online and how the U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education is working to get everyone connected, go to http://www.ed.gov/edblogs/ovae/2014/04/09/octae-is-working-to-get-everyone-on/

page.title: The PSTRE Activity: Monitor Progress
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-43.mp3

Audio transcript


Once the plan is made, it is time to use the resources and search for and gather the information. You will want to have students working in groups, at least the first few times that you engage in the activity in your class. Students working collaboratively are more likely to stay on track and manage problems that may occur. Depending on the level of your class, you are likely to want to provide work sheets that include the questions being asked, constraints that exist, or preorganize the information to be collected, to help students monitor their own progress. As a whole class, discuss the process of monitoring one’s own progress. It is an important strategy in PSTRE.

-Monitoring your own progress means
- Staying on track and attending to the goal or question at hand
- Being prepared to handle unexpected events (e.g., software incompatibility, a broken link, or conflicting information)
- Paying attention to progress toward the goal
- Staying aware of the constraints (e.g., in the Online Job Search Problem, that you don’t want to have to register or pay a fee)

You may elect to teach a mini-lesson on a grammar point or vocabulary that is important to understanding the information that the students may be finding in their search, in their interviews, or other data-collection sources. You can decide in advance on the mini-lesson to teach, or you can respond to the needs that arise in the process of working on the PSTRE activity.

Once the plan is made, it is time to use the resources and search for and gather the information.

Students working collaboratively are more likely to stay on track and manage problems that may occur.

Teacher-provided guides that include the questions being asked, constraints that exist or that pre-organize the information to be collected can also help students monitor progress.

Discuss the process of monitoring one’s own progress. It is an important strategy in PSTRE.

You may elect to teach a minilesson on a grammar point or vocabulary that is important to understanding the information that the students may be finding in their search, their interviews, or other data collection sources.

Monitoring one’s own progress means

  • Staying on track and attending to the goal or question at hand

  • Being prepared to handle unexpected events (e.g., software incompatibility, a broken link, or conflicting information)

  • Paying attention to progress toward the goal

  • Staying aware of the constraints (e.g., in the Online Job Search Problem: that you don’t want to have to register or pay a fee)

page.title: The PSTRE Activity: Select Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-44.mp3

Audio transcript


This is the step in the activity in which a lot of the student work happens; the students select the information needed for the solution. On the Internet, students search for the information, using the resources that they have already identified. As they find information, they evaluate possible sources for relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias or perspective. For more information about this process, see Unit 3, linked here. Teach mini-lessons, as needed, such as the language for writing an e-mail and the language for leaving a voicemail with the same information. You can provide guidance and support through guiding materials, such as a checklist of questions to ask to determine relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias or perspective for each source of information. In the case of the parent–teacher conference problem, the adult ELL students will look at a school website (ideally, a website of one of the group members’ kids’ school), look for things such as the calendar to see if parent–teacher conference information is there, look for class blogs, and look for the teachers’ e-mail addresses and phone/voicemail numbers.

In this phase, the students select the information that they need for the solution.

On the Internet, students will search for the information, evaluating possible sources for relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias or perspective. For more information about this process, see Unit 3 of this module.

Potential minilessons include the language for writing an e-mail and the language for leaving a voicemail with the same information.

Support can be provided through guiding materials, such as a checklist of questions to ask to determine relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias or perspective for each source of information.  

The Parent–Teacher Conference Problem: Select Information

The students will look at a school website (ideally, a website of one of the group members’ kids’ school), and look for the parent–teacher conference information in places such as

  • The school calendar

  • Class blogs

  • The teachers’ e-mail address

  • The school phone/voicemail numbers.

page.title: The PSTRE Activity: Make Use of the Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-45.mp3

Audio transcript


In this step, the students take the information that they have collected and organize or transform it in a way that will help them select a solution. There are many different ways that the students can organize or reorganize the information. For example, the information may be organized into a PowerPoint presentation to the class about a proposed solution (e.g., the computer to buy and Internet service to get) or into a table about information available on each job search website, as seen in the example on this page. Graphic organizers or note-taking formats can be useful in this step in the process.

In this step, a solution is reached or proposed. As the PSTRE activity concludes, it is important to discuss the problem-solving process and the way it can be used in real-world problems.

Job Search Website Information Included
Responsibilities Pay per hour Location*
1. www.jobscout.org Yes Yes No
2. 
3.
*Use to calculate travel distance from home.

In this step, the students take the information that they have collected and organize or transform it in a way to help select the solution.  

The information may be organized into many different forms, including a PowerPoint presentation to the class about a proposed solution or a table about information available on each job search website (see sample table).

Graphic organizers or note-taking formats can be useful in this step in the process.

In this step, a solution is reached or proposed.

As the PSTRE activity concludes, it is important to discuss the problem-solving process and the way it can be used in real-world problems.

To Go Deeper


To learn more about graphic organizers and note-taking techniques, see Meeting the Language Needs of Today's Adult English Language Learner: Professional Development Module, Unit 3: Incorporating Language Strategies for Success at All Levels of Adult ESL Instruction.

page.title: Final Things To Consider
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-46.mp3

Audio transcript


There are three things to keep in mind as general principles when integrating PSTRE into your courses and programs. The first is the importance of integration. Integrating problem-solving instruction into units is more effective than a teaching a course or workshop devoted to problem solving as a skill. The second is sustained practice. Adult learners need many opportunities to practice with new technologies and problem-solving skills. The practice needs to be distributed across time; so it is important to integrate activities that include problem solving across units, levels, and programs. In addition, PSTRE is a skill that benefits all learners, not just English language learners. The third thing to keep in mind is collaboration. Collaboration facilitates learning in the context of PSTRE. Students collaborating on problem-solving tasks are more likely to employ the activities of planning, monitoring, and evaluating in the problem-solving process. The ability to collaborate and work in groups is an important soft skill for both college and career readiness.

Integration

Integrating problem-solving instruction into units is more effective than teaching a course or workshop devoted to problem solving as a skill.

Sustained practice

Adult learners need many opportunities to practice new technologies and problem-solving skills. The practice needs to be distributed across time. Integrate activities that include problem solving across units, levels, and programs. PSTRE is a skill that benefits all learners, not just English language learners.

Collaboration

Collaboration facilitates learning in the context of PSTRE. Students collaborating on problem-solving tasks are more likely to engage in the activities
of planning, monitoring, and evaluating in the problem-solving process.

When you click on End you will see a page stating that you are finished with this lesson. Click on the link below to return to the main page of this unit and move on to the next activity.

page.title: Final Activity (administrators)
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-48.mp3

Audio transcript


As a teacher, you must reflect on your own learning, as well as on the ways to support the learning of the teachers and students in your program. Your own experiences as an adult learner in this course, as well as the information that you learned, can inform the decisions that you make in your own programs.

For this unit, there is one final question for reflection, and here it is: 2015 research indicates that administrators and teachers alike are enthusiastic about “the potential for technology to support instruction. Administrators and practitioners are open to and interested in thoughtful, appropriate deployment of technology to meet the needs and goals of their students” (Tyton Partners, 2015, p. 2). Despite this enthusiasm, teachers also report that lack of organizational support is one of the barriers to teachers’ use of technology in the classroom.

After taking the online course, what ideas do you have about supporting the development of digital skills in your program? What barriers exist? What are the potential solutions?

Thank you for taking the time to learn about integrating digital literacy in adult English language instruction!

Tyton Partners. (2015). Learning for life: The opportunity for technology to transform adult education. Part 1: Interest in and aptitude for technology.

Stamford, CT: Tyton Partners. (used with permission)

Learning for life: The opportunity for technology to transform adult education.

Part 1: Interest in and aptitude for technology.
Stamford, CT: Tyton Partners. Used with permission.

Question for reflection

2015 research indicates that administrators and teachers alike are enthusiastic about “the potential for technology to support instruction. Administrators and practitioners are open to and interested in thoughtful, appropriate deployment of technology to meet the needs and goals of their students”

(Tyton Partners, 2015, p. 2).

Despite this enthusiasm, teachers also report that lack of organizational support is one of the barriers to teachers’ use of technology in the classroom.  

After taking the online course, what ideas do you have about supporting the development of digital skills in your program? What barriers exist? What are the potential solutions?

Thank you for taking the time to learn about integrating digital literacy in adult English language instruction!

page.title: Final Activity (teachers)
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-48.mp3

Audio transcript


As a teacher, you must reflect on your own learning, as well as on the ways to support the learning of students in your classes. Your own experiences as an adult learner in this course, as well as the new information that you possess, can inform the decisions that you make in your own classes.

For the final activity of this unit, design a PSTRE activity that you might use in your own class. Design it so that you can use the same process in multiple units because, with technology, it is often good to try one new thing and do it widely. First, select one class that you teach that would benefit from additional language and digital literacy skill development and practice. Second, review the units in that class and select two or three that could benefit from a PSTRE activity. Pick one to detail for this activity. Third, design a problem-based activity, similar to the examples used here, to go with the unit. Fourth, create an activity that includes the five steps in problem solving, as appropriate for the purposes of the unit, as well as the language level and digital skills of your students. Last, enter information about your activity on the next page. For your convenience and to use as a guide, a list containing the three sample problems used in this unit is linked on this page.

For the final activity, design a PSTRE activity that you might use in your own class. With technology, it is often good to try one new thing and do it widely.

1. Select one class that you teach that would benefit from additional language and digital literacy skill development and practice.  

2. Review the curriculum units in that class and select two or three that could benefit from a PSTRE activity. Pick one to detail for this activity.

3. Design a problem, similar to the examples used here, to go with the unit.

4. Create an activity that includes the five steps in problem solving, as appropriate to the purposes of the unit, as well as the language level and digital skills of your students.

Sample problems used in this unit:

  • The Online Job Search Problem

  • The Parent-Teacher Conference Problem

  • The Buying-a-Computer Problem

page.title: You have completed unit 4
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-50.mp3

Audio transcript


Congratulations! You have completed Unit 4. As you work to integrate PSTRE into your classes, enjoy it! Ideally, you are working with colleagues who are interested in doing the same thing and are sharing ideas. If not, consider starting up such a group, either virtually or face to face. There is nothing like working with other teachers to spark creativity and enthusiasm for new teaching ideas. Good luck!

Congratulations!

You have completed Unit 4.

Thank you for participating in Unit 4 of Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction.

Enjoy integrating a PSTRE activity into your class!

If you would like to learn more about integrating digital literacy into your classes, you can participate in additional units in this module.

  • Unit 1: “Digital Literacy in Our lives”

  • Unit 2: “Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning”

  • Unit 3: “Digital Information Literacy”

A list of further resources is available here (printer-friendly version).

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
